content.title: ENERGY MODELLING TOOLS AND APPLICATIONS
content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2

content.text: Energy systems modelling is a computational process used to test hypotheses about energy systems, including scenarios of generation, distribution, and consumption. These models can be used to evaluate behavior and performance of energy systems (shown in the following figure) under different climatic, technical, economic and social conditions. Energy modelling encompasses various methods, from simple analytical calculations to complex simulations incorporating multiple variables and interactions within the energy sector.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: grid stability analysis
concepts.body: Grid stability analysis is the assessment of an electrical grid's ability to maintain consistent voltage and frequency levels during normal operation and after disturbances, ensuring reliable power supply.

concepts.title: renewable energy integration
concepts.body: The process of incorporating renewable energy sources, such as solar or wind, into the existing energy system to ensure a reliable and efficient energy supply.

concepts.title: scenario planning
concepts.body: Scenario planning is a strategic planning method used to make flexible long-term plans by envisioning and analyzing different future scenarios based on varying assumptions and uncertainties.

content.text: Energy modelling serves various purposes across different sectors and industries:
Policy Analysis and Development:
By simulating different energy policy scenarios, policymakers can assess potential impacts and make informed decisions about policy objectives, design, and implementation.
Energy System Planning and Optimization:

Energy models help optimize the mix of energy sources and technologies, plan for future energy demand—including the development of adequate energy infrastructure such as power networks—analyze energy security risks, and ensure the reliability and stability of energy supply.
Investment and Economic Analysis:
These models provide insights into the costs and benefits of different initiatives, technologies, and efficiency measures, supporting sound economic decision-making.
Environmental Impact Assessment:
Simulating various energy scenarios aids in evaluating emission reductions and other environmental benefits, thereby supporting environmental sustainability.
Evaluation of New and Emerging Technologies:
Energy modelling allows stakeholders to assess the potential contributions of innovative energy technologies to the overall energy mix and understand their implications for sustainability.
Resource Management:
It assists in evaluating the sustainable use of natural resources, including both renewable and non-renewable sources.
Climate Change Mitigation:
Energy modelling is crucial for designing strategies to mitigate climate change by providing a comprehensive understanding of energy system complexities.
Overall, energy modelling is indispensable for informed decision-making, sustainability, and ensuring the efficient use of energy resources.

An energy system encompasses an interconnected network of energy production, conversion, transmission, distribution, storage, and consumption, comprising physical components and processes essential for delivering energy services to end-users. Within this system, renewable energy sources (RES) play a pivotal role, offering sustainable energy options like solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, and biomass. In contrast, fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas, constitute non-renewable energy sources derived from ancient organic matter. Likewise, nuclear energy is currently produced from uranium and plutonium, and all nuclear fuels are finite resources. The energy mix refers to the combination of different energy sources used to meet energy demand in a specific region or country. However, concerns about greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions prompt the adoption of measures, such as carbon taxes, aimed at reducing GHG emissions and encouraging cleaner energy sources. Achieving net-zero emissions, i.e., balancing emitted and removed GHGs, is a key objective. The capacity factor, defined as the actual energy production of an energy generation unit (for example, a wind turbine or a solar plant) relative to maximum energy produced if unit had been operating at full capacity for the same period of time., Capacity factor is a measure of operational efficiency.

Scenario analysis evaluates potential energy pathways by simulating different conditions, policies, and technological developments. Optimization techniques, which employ mathematical methods to operate energy systems efficiently, consider multiple objectives and constraints. Decentralized energy systems involve generation near point of use, often with smaller-scale renewables like rooftop solar. Capacity expansion entails planning and investing in new energy generation resources to meet future demand and replace aging infrastructure. Curtailment is reducing renewable energy output due to oversupply or grid limitations.

The modernization, decentralization, and decarbonization efforts toward energy sector transformation strongly rely on data-driven and evidence-based decision-making insights that drive ongoing initiatives for sustainable energy development. A key driver for this transformation is the synergistic interplay of the data value chain, artificial intelligence, and energy modelling for optimized stakeholder and system decision support. Crucial data are collected from various energy applications and, through data analytics, embedded with actionable intelligence that informs strategies for the evolving sustainable energy landscape. This further equips policymakers, governments, and supporting organizations with informed, intelligent insights that lead to effective collaborative strategies for creating enabling environments for sustainable energy adoption. This functionality hinges on the accessibility of high-quality data for targeted energy modelling interventions that inform energy development strategies, drive innovation, and monitor development progress.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 3 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Types of Energy Models

content.text: Descriptive models

Descriptive energy models are used to represent and analyze the current state and historical trends of energy systems. These models provide a detailed and comprehensive understanding of how energy systems have evolved over time and how they currently operate. Unlike predictive or optimization models, descriptive models focus on accurately describing existing conditions rather than forecasting future scenarios or optimizing resource allocation. Descriptive models rely heavily on empirical data to reflect the actual performance and characteristics of energy systems. They use historical data on energy production, consumption, prices, and other relevant parameters. They are used for benchmarking current performance, identifying trends, and understanding historical energy system dynamics. LEAP is a descriptive model widely used for energy policy analysis and climate change mitigation assessment. It is a flexible, data-driven model that can represent energy systems at various levels of detail used by governments, NGOs, and research institutions to understand current energy systems and evaluate the impacts of different energy policies.
Prescriptive Models

Prescriptive energy models are designed to provide specific recommendations and guidelines for achieving desired outcomes in energy systems. These models often involve optimization techniques to identify the best strategies for resource allocation, technology deployment, and policy implementation. The goal is to prescribe actions that lead to improved efficiency, reduced emissions, and enhanced sustainability of energy systems. These models use mathematical optimization techniques to determine the best possible solutions under given constraints. This involves minimizing or maximizing an objective function, such as cost, emissions, or energy use. OSeMOSYS is one typical example and it has been used to prescribe energy transition pathways for different countries, for example, Kenya.
Predictive models

Predictive energy models are designed to forecast future energy demand, supply, and system behavior based on various assumptions and input data. These models use historical data and statistical techniques to predict how energy systems will evolve under different scenarios. The primary purpose of predictive models is to inform planning and decision-making by providing insights into potential future states of the energy system. Predictive models use statistical methods and algorithms to estimate future energy demand, supply, prices, and other relevant parameters. These models evaluate different scenarios to understand how changes in variables such as economic growth, population, technology adoption, and policy measures will impact future energy systems. EnergyPLAN is a tool for advanced energy system analysis that includes the ability to simulate and predict future energy demand and supply under various scenarios, mainly used for national and regional energy planning, including the integration of renewable energy sources. Predictive energy models are essential tools for anticipating future energy system dynamics. By providing insights into potential future states and identifying risks and opportunities, these models support informed decision-making and strategic planning in the energy sector.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 3 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Applications of Energy Modelling

content.text: Scenario analysis is a powerful application of energy modelling that allows policymakers and planners to explore alternative futures and assess the potential impacts of different policy decisions, technological developments, and external factors on the energy system. By developing and analyzing multiple scenarios, decision-makers can better understand the uncertainties and trade-offs involved in energy planning and make informed decisions to achieve desired outcomes. Policymakers use energy models to develop scenarios that represent different policy options and regulatory frameworks, such as carbon pricing, renewable energy targets, and energy efficiency standards.

Energy models are used to explore scenarios that reflect the adoption and deployment of specific technologies, such as renewable energy sources, energy storage systems, electric vehicles, low-emissions hydrogen, and smart grids. Policymakers use scenario analysis to evaluate the potential impacts of proposed policies and regulations on energy supply, demand, prices, emissions, and economic indicators. Scenario analysis for policy and planning provides decision-makers with valuable insights into the potential impacts and trade-offs associated with different energy strategies and policy options. By considering a range of plausible future scenarios, policymakers can develop robust and adaptive energy policies that promote sustainability, resilience, and economic prosperity.
Load forecasting and demand management

Load forecasting and demand management are essential components of energy modelling that help utilities, grid operators, and energy planners anticipate future electricity demand and optimize the operation of the power system. Energy models are used to analyze historical consumption patterns, demographic trends, weather data, and economic indicators to develop accurate forecasts of electricity load and implement strategies for demand-side management. Short-term load forecasting involves predicting electricity demand over hours, days, or weeks ahead. Energy models use statistical techniques, time series analysis, and machine learning algorithms to analyze historical load data and incorporate factors such as weather conditions, day of the week, and holidays.

Demand management strategies aim to reduce peak electricity demand by implementing measures such as demand response programs, time-of-use pricing, and energy efficiency incentives. Energy models help assess the effectiveness of these strategies and optimize their implementation to minimize costs and enhance grid stability (Wang et al., 2019).
Integration of renewable energy sources

Energy modelling plays a crucial role in the integration of renewable energy sources (RES) into the electricity grid and ensuring grid stability amidst increasing variability and uncertainty. By simulating different scenarios and assessing the impacts of renewable energy deployment, energy models help policymakers, grid operators, and utilities design resilient and efficient energy systems that incorporate a higher share of intermittent generation, usually from renewable sources. Energy models assist in planning the optimal mix and capacity of renewable energy technologies (e.g., solar photovoltaic, wind turbines) to meet future electricity demand while considering factors such as resource availability, technology costs, and grid constraints. Models analyze the spatial distribution of renewable resources and their temporal variability to identify suitable locations for renewable energy projects and optimize their operation and integration into the grid. Energy models assess the compatibility of renewable energy projects with existing grid infrastructure and evaluate the need for grid upgrades, reinforcements, and flexibility measures to accommodate variable and intermittent generation.
Grid Stability: Frequency and Voltage Regulation

Models simulate the dynamic behavior of renewable energy sources and their impact on grid frequency stability. They analyze the effectiveness of frequency regulation mechanisms, such as automatic generation control and grid-scale energy storage, in maintaining grid stability. Such models fall under power system models and are also used to evaluate the impact of renewable energy integration on grid voltage profiles and assess the need for reactive power compensation, voltage regulation devices, and grid reinforcement measures to ensure voltage stability and reliability. Renewable energy integration and grid stability are critical for transitioning to a sustainable energy future. Energy modelling provides valuable insights and tools for policymakers and stakeholders to optimize renewable energy deployment, enhance grid stability, and ensure reliable and resilient electricity supply.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 3 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Tanzania

content.text: Overview

Climate change has necessitated the reexamination of energy systems worldwide, as it has emerged that energy production and consumption are the leading contributors of carbon emissions. For effective energy transition to be achieved, energy modelling should be extensively used so that the intended transition can be sustainable.

Tanzania is one of the countries under the Regional Bureau of Africa and is in the process of weighing different pathways that lead to a sustainable energy transition. It is a country that had an electricity access rate of 38 % as of 2019 and the electricity mix is largely dominated by hydropower generation. Tanzania aims to achieve 75 % electricity access by 2025 through the expansion of the national grid or use of mini-grid1. To assess the possibility of achieving universal access and at the same time achieving a clean electricity generation mix, two modelling tools were used; Python for Power System Analysis (PyPSA) and Geographical Information System tool. The study assessed two scenarios: the Power System Masterplan (PSMP) Scenario and the Clean Energy Transition Tanzania (CETT) Scenario. The first scenario modeled generation expansion based on the least-cost generation expansion approach, where all available technologies were evaluated and selected based on their operational costs to meet demand. This scenario did not consider GHG emissions or universal access to electricity. It was found that under this scenario, emissions continued to rise until 2050, and some communities remained without power. This indicates that focusing solely on the cost of the power system leads to unsustainable electricity development, as it neglects environmental impacts and electricity access rates.

The second scenario aimed to achieve universal access by 2030 and reduce emissions to zero by 2050, using the least-cost generation expansion modeling approach. This scenario incorporated environmental, economic, and social aspects, aiming to achieve Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 7. However, the results revealed that the investment required to achieve these goals is enormous, making public funds alone insufficient to build a sustainable power system of this magnitude. The study highlighted that private investors and development agencies are crucial for clean energy development. It also identified barriers to universal access to electricity and low-carbon electricity sectors that could hinder these two players in clean energy development. To encourage investment in the clean energy industry, the study recommends that the government create an enabling environment by allowing market forces to determine electricity prices, fostering the development of strong and independent institutions, and using auction systems for investments in the renewable energy sector. The tools used in the study make it replicable, but the challenge lies in understanding the type of data solicited from engaged stakeholders and how it was implemented.

content.title: Part 3: Data Value Chain and Energy Modelling: Synergies and Interdependencies

content.text: The data value chain process is a critical lever for providing quality data for energy modelling processes. Its robust data lifecycle enables targeted data collection, management, and governance, ensuring that quality insights are derived for and accessible to relevant stakeholders. The effectiveness of energy modelling is determined by the quality and completeness of the data it receives, which is crucial for targeted strategy development and resource mobilization.

Energy modelling relies on heterogeneous datasets, such as weather patterns, energy consumption, energy generation levels, decentralized energy system asset performance, energy infrastructure, land and resource utilization, and socio-economic and geopolitical indicators. These datasets are aggregated for building and calibrating energy models. The integrity and quality of these datasets hinge on the effectiveness of data management and governance strategies throughout the value chain, contributing to the reliability of the model and more informed decisions.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Energy modelling is a cornerstone for strategic energy system transformation.
takeaways.description: By simulating diverse scenarios—ranging from policy impacts to renewable energy integration—energy models provide critical insights for optimizing resource allocation, enhancing grid stability, and achieving decarbonization goals. These tools enable policymakers to navigate complex trade-offs and design adaptive strategies for sustainable energy transitions.

takeaways.title: The synergy between the data value chain and energy modelling drives precision and reliability.
takeaways.description: High-quality, heterogeneous datasets—such as weather patterns, energy consumption, and socio-economic indicators—are essential for building and calibrating accurate energy models. Robust data management and governance ensure that models deliver actionable insights, supporting informed decision-making and effective resource mobilization.

takeaways.title: Data visualization is a strategic tool for actionable energy insights.
takeaways.description: Effective data visualization transforms complex energy data into clear, actionable narratives, enhancing decision-making and stakeholder communication. By adhering to best practices in design and storytelling, energy professionals can create visualizations that highlight key trends, such as energy consumption patterns or infrastructure performance, ensuring data-driven strategies are both accessible and impactful.
